entry.et: American Spanish cañón, probably alteration of obsolete Spanish callón, augmentative of calle street, from Latin callis footpath

def.dt: :a deep narrow valley with steep sides and often with a stream flowing through it
:something resembling a canyon the city's concrete canyons

entry.et: Middle English canon, from Anglo-French, from Old Italian cannone, literally, large tube, augmentative of canna reed, tube, from Latin, cane, reed cane

def.dt: :a large heavy gun usually mounted on a carriage
:a heavy-caliber automatic aircraft gun firing explosive shells
:the projecting part of a bell by which it is hung :ear
:the part of the leg in which the cannon bone is found

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English, from Late Latin, from Latin, ruler, rule, model, standard, from Greek kanōn

def.dt: :a regulation or dogma decreed by a church council
:a provision of canon law
def.set: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin, from Latin, model
def.dt: :the most solemn and unvarying part of the Mass including the consecration of the bread and wine
def.set: Middle English, from Late Latin, from Latin, standard
def.dt: :an authoritative list of books accepted as Holy Scripture
:the authentic works of a writer
:a sanctioned or accepted group or body of related works the canon of great literature
:an accepted principle or rule
:a criterion or standard of judgment
:a body of principles, rules, standards, or norms
def.set: Late Greek kanōn, from Greek, model
def.dt: :a contrapuntal musical composition in which each successively entering voice presents the initial theme usually transformed in a strictly consistent way

entry.et: Middle English canoun, from Anglo-French *canoun, chanoun, from Late Latin canonicus one living under a rule, from Latin, according to rule, from Greek kanonikos, from kanōn

def.dt: :a clergyman belonging to the chapter or the staff of a cathedral or collegiate church
:canon regular
reservation NE Arizona containing cliff-dweller ruins
canyon of Colorado River between Arizona & Nevada S of Hoover Dam
canyon of the Gunnison SW cen Colorado partly in Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park
canyon S Utah containing curiously eroded pinnacles
dam N Arizona in Glen Canyon of Colorado River forming Lake Pow*ell ggglen02.wavˈpau̇(-ə)l (chiefly in SE Utah)

gorge of the Colorado NW Arizona extending from mouth of the Little Colorado W to the Grand Wash Cliffs; over 1 miles (1.6 kilometers) deep; area largely within Grand Canyon National Park see marble canyon
